Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the design document half-finished. My phone buzzed with another Slack message from the product team, asking for my input on the new feature. The deadline was looming, and I knew the other teams were waiting on me to move forward. My mind raced with technical details, diagrams, and the pressure to deliver something solid and innovative. At the same time, I glanced at the clock—Sunday morning. The church service would start soon. I remembered the warmth of worship, the sense of belonging, and the expectation from my church community to be present, to serve, to connect. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. If I stayed home to work, I’d let down my church family and miss the spiritual renewal I craved. If I went to church, I’d risk delaying the project and disappointing my colleagues. My heart tugged in both directions, torn between my commitment to my faith and my responsibility as a developer. I closed my eyes, wrestling with the impossible choice, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me.
